awd_titl_txt: Society for Developmental Biology Annual Meetings 2019-2021
awd_abstract_narration:
The quintessential question, "How does a single, fertilized egg cell produce all the different cell types, tissues and organs of the adult organism?", and the genetic, molecular and cellular mechanisms that conduct these complex processes are study objectives of the field of developmental biology.  The Society for Developmental Biology (previously the Society for the Study of Development and Growth) annual meetings have provided the forum for reporting of new findings, as well as exchange of ideas and cross-fertilization of new methods among developmental biologists around the World since 1939 (except for two years during WWII).  Cutting edge technologies have moved the field into the genomic era and allowed the investigators to analyze and monitor the processes leading a single fertilized egg to a complete individual, from plant to invertebrates to vertebrates including human; to understand how cells and tissues may change from normal to disease; and why some tissues are able to regenerate while others cannot.  These new technologies have also raised awareness for ethical practices and the SDB annual meetings have also provided the venue for rational discourse.  

The three annual meetings of this proposal aim to continue to be the primary meeting venue for scientists in this and related fields world-wide, with plenary and concurrent sessions with talks by seasoned and new investigators, dedicated poster sessions and workshops/roundtables on topics of special and current interest.  In keeping with the educational mission of the Society, we will offer professional development workshops for trainees and pre-tenure faculty (Boot Camp for New Faculty), education symposia, postdoctoral symposia and networking opportunities for all.  One feature that makes this meeting different from other scientific societies' meetings is the Hilde Mangold Postdoctoral Symposium, where two postdoctoral fellows review all eligible abstracts from their peers, select the top eight for short talks and co-chair the symposium.  They practice peer review and session chairmanship under the mentoring of the SDB president, a critical career training for these junior scientists.  We also will focus to provide a welcoming, inclusive and respectful atmosphere for the participants, to encourage frank exchange of ideas and fomenting of future collaborations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

OUTCOME REPORT

The Society for Developmental Biology (SDB) was founded in 1939 and since then has held annual meetings except for two years, during World War II.  The meeting format evolved and since 1996 it has been an open forum for all levels of investigators, from undergraduate students to experienced investigators, presenting their most recent research findings.  There are plenary and concurrent sessions, special interest and postdoctoral symposia, workshops on education, new methods and research areas, poster sessions, theme table discussions, and various opportunities for the budding scientists to meet and interact with the more senior investigators.  This current grant supported the meetings held from 2019 in Boston to 2022 in Vancouver, including the two COVID pandemic years (2020 and 2021) as virtual events.

The Boston meeting, celebrating the Society’s 80th Birthday,  was one of the largest held, with 949 registrants from 26 different countries.  Even the closing down of the World due to the COVID pandemic did not stop the inquisitive minds of scientists as 2,486 people from 44 countries registered for the virtual event.  While the attendance in the second lockdown year dropped to 1,296 from 32 countries, probably because many more virtual scientific conferences became available, it affirms the benefits of this remote format, which allows people who cannot travel to attend meetings important to their research.  The joint SDB and Pan-American Society for Evolutionary and Developmental Biology (PASEDB) Meeting was in 2022, in Vancouver, Canada, returning to in-person formal, and bringing 700 registrants from 19 countries.           

Even though the in-person and virtual formats were very different, the program committees were able to preserve the basic agenda:

- Presidential Symposium - with focus on major current questions in the field: Development: From Deconstruction to Reconstruction; Development at Multiple Scales; Translating Developmental Biology and Developmental Biology in a Changing World.

- Plenary Sessions - two to three at each meeting addressing topics of broad interest by invited speakers, followed by 1-minute ‘poster-teaser’ talks selected from abstracts to highlight the most notable posters.

- Concurrent Sessions - nine sessions at each meeting covering more specialized topics in developmental biology and related areas. In addition to the invited speakers, short talks were selected from the submitted abstracts to give an opportunity for more junior participants to showcase their excellent work to a broader audience. This is a very competitive process, with a couple hundred abstracts usually being considered for around 30 slots.

- Special Interest Symposium - a session organized by SDB’s Inclusion & Outreach Committee and Professional Development & Education Committee, with experts discussing subjects related to life in science and academia, with follow-up workshops for further discussion.  Topics covered include abuse of power and harassment, biases and discrimination, mental wellness, and climate change.  

- Hilde Mangold Postdoctoral Symposium - a session organized and co-chaired by postdoctoral fellows featuring talks by fellow postdocs selected from a pool of submitted abstracts.  This very competitive session is well attended because the speakers are polished and many in the audience look for faculty candidates in their departments. 

- Poster Sessions - are the highlight of the meetings as many undergraduate and graduate students present their work to an international audience, many for the first time.  Winners of best poster competition receive various awards.

- Networking sessions - many additional sessions, including receptions, allow investigators at all levels to meet up, exchange ideas, receive advice, and obtain information from the funding agencies’ representatives. 

Intellectual Merit:  The meetings allow developmental biologists around the World to share their breakthroughs and provide a forum for cross-fertilization of new ideas and methods, contributing to the advancement of the field.  The larger attendance at the virtual meetings due to the COVID pandemic encouraged us to provide on-demand remote access to talks after the in-person meetings for those who were interested in the sessions but could not travel.  This expanded the availability and dissemination of new information for a wider audience not captured in-person.

Broader Impacts:  The meetings offer sessions connecting foundational knowledge to its applications to life and the planet; opportunities to foster young scientists entering the field, especially the under-represented and underserved populations; sessions to help researcher to be more effective mentors and teachers for the next generation and the public.  They provide a forum on topics relevant to establishing national policies for research and public understanding of science and its beneficial practices in agriculture and animal (including human) health, and to the well-being of our planet and its biodiversity.
